title: 121st Problem 2016
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/IyALVwktBR-parallel-circuit.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given the parallel circuit above with the following values:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" { R }_{ 1 }=100\Omega \\ \\ { R }_{ 2 }=300\Omega \\ \\ { R }_{ 3 }=600\Omega \\ \\ { V }_{ T }=150V "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"  { P }_{ T } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (Total Power) of the circuit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Part One."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Check out the set: 2016 Problems."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is the last part of a problem."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Adding the two fractional expressions gives 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{x+1}{x+1}+\frac{y+2}{y+2} +\frac{z+2015}{z+2015} = 3,"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
so our unknown value must be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3-\frac{1}{2} = \frac{5}{2} = 2.5."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            There may be infinite number of possible values for x, y, and z satisfying the first equation. But inserting the values of x, y and z (that satisfy the first equation) on the second equation will always yield to 2.5 as proven by Saunak. Your second expression has quite a mistake in basic division. The second fraction should be 2, not -2. Therefore, 0.5 + 2 + 0 = 2.5.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            X=5  Z=2015*5 Y=10 also satifies!Nice solution!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            x=1, y=-4, z=0"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The first expression is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {1}{1+1}+\frac {2}{-4+2}+\frac {2015}{0+2015} = \frac {1}{2}-1+1 = \frac {1}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The second is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac {1}{1+1}+\frac {-4}{-4+2}+\frac {0}{0+2015} = \frac {1}{2}+-2+0 = -\frac {3}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Any solution where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" z=\frac {2015(xy+4x+3y+10)}{xy-2x-y-6} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will work. There aren't just multiple solutions, there are uncountably infinite solutions.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Why do you assume that x must be zero - it is a lucky guess in this case, but the logic of how you got there escapes me - especially given your first statement that x must be infinity.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 1222...² Problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"12² = 144 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
21² = 441 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
122² = 14884 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
221² = 48841 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
1222² = 1493284 "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
2221² = 4932841     "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Does this property exist for all 1222... numbers?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We define "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1)^{(n)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with parenthesis at the power position, to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" repetitions of digit "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", in decimal representation. For instance "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1)^{(2)}=11"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1)^{(3)}=111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The numbers of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1222..."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits in total, can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^n+2\times (1)^{(n-1)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Take it to the power two to have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^{2n}+4\times \big( (1)^{(n-1)} \big)^2+4\times10^n\times (1)^{(n-1)} \ (*) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The swapped version of  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1222..."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be written as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10\times 2 \times  (1)^{(n-1)}+1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Its square is"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10^2\times 4\times \big( (1)^{(n-1)} \big)^2+1+40 \times (1)^{(n-1)} \ (**)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In order to have the property true, we need the following to be true (the LHS is from ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"*"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), when the digit "1", from the beginning is dropped. the RHS is from ("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"**"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), when digit "1", from the end, is subtracted and the remaining is divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":")."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4\times \big( (1)^{(n-1)} \big)^2+4\times10^n\times (1)^{(n-1)}=(\frac{1}{10})\times \{10^2\times 4\times \big( (1)^{(n-1)} \big)^2+40 \times (1)^{(n-1)}\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"the equation, above, can be simplified to"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(10^n-1)\times (1)^{(n-1)}=9\times ((1)^{(n-1)})^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"or"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(10^{n-1}+\dots+1)\times (1)^{(n-1)}=((1)^{(n-1)})^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"which can be proven, knowing the definition of multiplication."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thing to prove: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1222…² = 1ABC…  (ABC… represents a sequence of digits that are the same in both numbersl) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"222…1² = ABC..1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Proof: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1222…       (222.. shall represent n number of twos) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 10ⁿ + 222… "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 10ⁿ + 2/9 * 999…  (999.. also represents n number of nines) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 10ⁿ + 2/9 * (10ⁿ - 1) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 11/9 * 10ⁿ - 2/9 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"222…1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 1 + 222…0 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 1 + 10 * 222… "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 1 + 10 * 2/9 * 999… "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 1 + 10 * 2/9 * (10ⁿ - 1) "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 20/9 * 10ⁿ - 11/9 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we must find out how many digits the number 1222…² has. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10ⁿ     <        1222…           <        10ⁿ * √10 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(10ⁿ)²      <        (1222…)²        <        (10ⁿ * √10)² "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"log10(10ⁿ)² <        log10(1222…)²       <        log10(10ⁿ * √10)² "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2n      <        x           <        2n + 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the number 1222…² must have 2n digits after the 1. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For this next step we’ll call 1ABC… the variable name a. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 1ABC… "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 10²ⁿ + ABC…     |-10²ⁿ "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a - 10²ⁿ = ABC…         | *10 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * (a - 10²ⁿ) = ABC…0     | +1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * (a - 10²ⁿ) + 1 = ABC…1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we can replace the a with 1ABC… . "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * (1ABC… - 10²ⁿ) + 1 = ABC…1 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can now replace 1ABC… with 1222…² and replace ABC…1 with 222…1². "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * (1222…² - 10²ⁿ) + 1 = 222…1² "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For our last step we can subtitute the numbers 1222… and 222…1 with their respective definitions. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * ((11/9 * 10ⁿ - 2/9)² - 10²ⁿ) + 1 = (20/9 * 10ⁿ - 11/9)² "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * (121/81 * 10²ⁿ - 44/81 * 10ⁿ + 4/81 - 10²ⁿ) + 1 = 400/81 * 10²ⁿ - 440/81 * 10ⁿ + 121/81    | *81 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10 * (121 * 10²ⁿ - 44 * 10ⁿ + 4 - 81 * 10²ⁿ) + 81 = 400 * 10²ⁿ - 440 * 10ⁿ + 121 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1210 * 10²ⁿ - 440 * 10ⁿ + 40 - 810 * 10²ⁿ + 81 = 400 * 10²ⁿ - 440 * 10ⁿ + 121 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"400 * 10²ⁿ - 440 * 10ⁿ + 121 = 400 * 10²ⁿ - 440 * 10ⁿ + 121 | -400 * 10²ⁿ + 440 * 10ⁿ - 121 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 = 0 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This equation is true so our original assumtion must have also been true."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
